On Jan 21, 2006, at 9:06 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> hdpoliya wrote:
>
>> But to my knowlege, your experience is against the theory of software
>> engineering. We suggest that during developing, the testers of a
>> program should not be the ones developed it.
>> I am confused.
>
> It is true that this has been common opinion in the software  
> community,
> but that opinion is changing.
>
> I would say this: the programmers should not be the /only/ one who  
> test
> the code they write.

I concur with both of these statements.  The point is that the  
Development and the QA Teams must be working together in harmony for  
a project to be successful.  This requires both continuous, clear  
communication and the rejection of the myth that "Developers just  
develop and testers just test."

Perhaps a good analogy would be a basketball forward who thinks, "I  
don't really need to work on my dribbling, the guards always bring up  
the ball."

> -- 
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice

Daryl
